page.title: Euro gold and silver commemorative coins (Finland)

revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox country|maxwidth=250px|width=250px | native_name = ''''''Finland'''''' | conventional_long_name = Finland | image_map = Location Finland EU Europe.png }} '''Euro gold and silver commemorative coins''' are special [[euro coins]] [[Mint (coin)|minted]] and issued by member states of the [[Eurozone]], mainly in gold and silver, although other [[precious metal]]s are also used in rare occasions. [[Finland]] was one of the first twelve countries in the Eurozone that introduced the [[Euro|euro (â¬)]] on 1 January 2002. Since then, the Mint of Finland Ltd. have been minting both normal issues of [[Finnish euro coins]], which are intended for circulation, and commemorative euro coins in gold and silver. These special coins have a [[legal tender]] only in Finland, unlike the normal issues of the Finnish euro coins, which have a legal tender in every country of the Eurozone. This means that the commemorative coins made of gold and silver cannot be used as money in other countries. Furthermore, as their [[Precious metal#Bullion|bullion value]]Precious metals in bulk form are known as ''bullion'', and are traded on [[commodity market]]s. Bullion metals may be cast into [[ingot]]s, or minted into [[coin]]s. The defining attribute of bullion is that it is valued by its mass and purity rather than by a [[face value]] as money. generally vastly exceeds their face value, these coins are not intended to be used as means of payment at allâalthough it remains possible. For this reason, they are usually named '''Collectors' coins'''. The coins usually [[Commemorative coin|commemorate]] the [[Anniversary|anniversaries]] of [[History|historical events]] or draw attention to [[current events]] of special importance. Finland mints four of these coins on average per year, in both gold and silver, with face value ranging from 5 to 100 euros. == Summary == As of 2 October 2008, 26 variations of Finnish commemorative coins have been minted: three in 2002, four in 2003, three in 2004, four in 2005, five in 2006, four in 2007, four in 2008 and one in 2009 so far. These special high-value commemorative coins are not to be confused with [[â¬2 commemorative coins]], which are coins designated for circulation and do have legal tender status in all countries of the Eurozone.{{cite web | publisher=[[European Commission]] | url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/the_euro/notes_coins8787_en.htm | title=Different types of euro coins | accessdate=2008-06-24}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} The following table shows the number of coins minted per year. In the first section, the coins are grouped by the metal used, while in the second section they are grouped by their face value. {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- | rowspan="2" On the reverse, a feather (as a symbol of an author) and [[Elias LÃ¶nnrot]]'s signature can be seen. The Finnish word ''kansanrunous'' (People's Poetry) can be observed on this side of the coin. |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 50th anniversary of the [[1952 Summer Olympics|Helsinki Olympic Games]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Erkki Vainio & Hannu Veijalainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''

Note that Finland is the only country highlighted on earth, as a representation of the host of these games. On the reverse, a view of the [[Helsinki Olympic Stadium]] can be seen. On the right, the 500 markka commemorative coin minted in 1952 celebrating the occasion is depicted.{{cite web | url=http://www.olympic.org/upload/collectors/object/CLO_228_MEDIUM.jpg | title=Helsinki 1952 500 Markka commemorative coin | publisher=Official website of the Olympic Movement | accessdate=2008-10-02}} |} ==2003 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[2003 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|Ice Hockey World Championships 2003]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' [[Pertti MÃ¤kinen]] | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:'''

Notice the number of elements (three) repeated twice, in both sides of the coin, as a representation of the year this coin was minted. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Finnish Numismatic Art |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Matti Peltokangas | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬50 | align=center | '''Alloy:'''
Disk: Au 750 (Gold)
Ring: Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 10,600 | align=center | '''Quality:''' [[Coin grading#Overview|Proof]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2003 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|27.25|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|12.8|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬250-â¬290{{cite web | url=http://www.eurocoins.com/templates/product.asp?ProductGuid=EUSU2003G1&GroupGuid=12037 | title=The Finnish Numismatic Art coin | publisher=eurocoins.com | accessdate=2008-10-02}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The snowflake featured on both sides of the coin symbolizes the country's northern location, where the designs spill over from the gold core to the silver ring. The [[bead]]s around the border are a traditional design element in Finnish numismatic art, dating back to the gold coins of 1878. The reverse features another design of snowflake surrounded by beads. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Anders Chydenius]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Tero Lounas | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''

â¬33-â¬65
â¬38.95 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This commemorative coin was minted in honour of the life work of [[Anders Chydenius]]. The year 2003 marked the 200th anniversary of the death of Chydenius, who served as, among other things, a priest, economist, and parliament member. The obverse features an open book, referring to Chydenius's numerous publications and the Bible. A traditional village with a church and other buildings can be seen on the reverse.{{cite web | url=http://www.rahapaja.fi/en/press-releases/chydenius/ | title=Commemorative coin in honour of the life work of Anders Chydenius | accessdate=2008-10-02 | publisher=Mint of Finland}} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim|Mannerheim]] and [[Saint Petersburg]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Anneli SipilÃ¤inen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''

The reverse of the coin features a view of [[Saint Petersburg]], with the [[Peter and Paul Fortress]] and its three turrets. In the coin the words "St. Petersburg 1703â2003" can be seen. |} ==2004 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Albert Edelfelt]] and painting |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' [[Pertti MÃ¤kinen]] | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 900 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 15,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' [[Coin grading#Overview|Proof]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2004 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|22|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|8.64|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬250-â¬340{{cite web | url=http://www.eurocoins.com/templates/product.asp?ProductGuid=EUSU2004G1&GroupGuid=12037 | title=Albert Edelfelt and painting coin | publisher=eurocoins.com | accessdate=2008-10-02}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] of the coin features a hanging flower and a corner of a fan, both symbols of beauty. The reverse design features three [[Moomin|Moomin characters]]; Moomintroll, The Snork Maiden, and Little My. |} ==2005 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[2005 World Championships in Athletics|10th IAAF World Championships in Athletics]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Pertti MÃ¤kinen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬20 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 900 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 30,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' [[Coin grading#Overview|Proof]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 17 May 2005 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|13.9|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|1.73|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬90 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This coin was the first coin celebrating the [[2005 World Championships in Athletics|10th IAAF World Championships in Athletics]] arranged in [[Helsinki]] in August 2005. The coin was issued in a sporty atmosphere. The coin was launched by [[javelin throw]]er [[Aki Parviainen]] and [[hammer throw]]er [[Olli-Pekka Karjalainen]]. The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] of the coin features [[Helsinki Olympic Stadium]] and above the stadium random waves express the feeling of the games. On the [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] are two faces with twelve euro stars on their hairs.{{cite web | url=http://www.rahapaja.fi/en/press-releases/1183/ | title=First â10th IAAF World Championships in Athleticsâ collector coin | publisher=Mint of Finland | accessdate=2008-10-02}} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[2005 World Championships in Athletics|10th IAAF World Championships in Athletics]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Tapio Kettunen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:'''
Center: Cu (Copper) & Ni (Nickel)
Ring: Al (Aluminium) & Pr (Bronze) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 175,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' [[Coin grading#Overview|BU]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 04.08.2005 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|35|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|19.8|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬14.95 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This coin was minted to celebrate [[2005 World Championships in Athletics|Finland's World Champion's in Athletics tournament]]. Fitting into the theme, on the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] of the coin, a [[javelin throw]]er is depicted. On the [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]], legs of hurdle runners with the [[Helsinki Olympic Stadium]] tower in the background can be seen.{{cite web | url=http://www.rahapaja.fi/en/press-releases/1274/ | title=Finland's World Champion's in Athletics issued the 5 euro collector coin | publisher=Mint of Finland | accessdate=2008-10-02}} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 60 Years of Peace |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' [[Pertti MÃ¤kinen]] | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''

â¬32-â¬59{{cite web | url=http://eurocoins.com/templates/product.asp?ProductGuid=EUSU2005S1P&GroupGuid=12039 | title=60 Years of Peace | publisher=eurocoins.com | accessdate=2008-10-02}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The obverse of the coin shows a dove carrying a twig in its beak. Below is the chain from which the dove has broken free, as well as the symbol of the [[Europa Coins|Europa Coins Programme]]. The reverse of the coin is divided into two parts, where the lower part symbolizes the frosted ground and wartime, and the top part symbolizes the bright sky and peace. From the harsh ground, where only thorns have previously grown, a plant blooms as it grows and stretches for the freedom of the surface. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"|

The Finnish phrase ''tuntematon sotilas'' (unknown soldier) can be seen in this side of the coin. The reverse has an embossed uniformed soldier standing at attention, shaped as a filmstrip. |} ==2006 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Presidency of the Council of the European Union|Finnish EU Presidency 2006]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:'''
Center: Cu (Copper) & Ni (Nickel)
Ring: Al (Aluminium) & Pr (Bronze) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 100,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' [[Coin grading#Overview|BU]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2006 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|35.0|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|18.7|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬13-â¬15{{cite web | url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=941 | title=Finnish EU Presidency 2006 coin | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Finnish EU Presidency 2006 |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬50 | align=center | '''Alloy:'''
Center: Au 750 (Gold)
Ring: Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 8,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' [[Coin grading#Overview|Proof]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2006 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|27.25|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|12.8|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬295 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| These two coins feature a silver colored center and gold colored ring, made with two different materials giving them their respective values. On the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]], a negotiation table, symbolized by the rectangular eminence, depicts the Presidency. The vertical text SUOMI â FINLAND and the horizontal year date (2006), together form a stylized gavel can be seen. There are balloons on the sides, filled with compositions of letters. The uniqueness design of this coin is that the pictorial subject of the [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] imitates the theme of the obverse. The entire pattern is made up of letters. Looking carefully you see a human face and balloons as well. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 150th Anniversary of [[Treaty of Paris (1856)|Demilitarisation of Ãland Islands]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Pertti MÃ¤kinen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' [[Nordic Gold]] | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 55,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' BU |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2006 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|35|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|18.7|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬13-â¬15{{cite web | url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=337 | title=150th Anniversary of Demilitarisation of Ãland Islands | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The obverse depicts a pine tree, very typical in the [[Ãland Islands]]. The reverse design features a boat's stern and rudder, with a dove perched on the tiller, a symbol of 150 years of peace. An interesting characteristic of this coin is that the text "150 years" and "the demilitarisation of Ãland" is written on the obverse of the coin in Swedish, and on the edge of the coin in Finnish. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Johan Vilhelm Snellman]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Tapio Kettunen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''
7,000
48,000 | align=center | '''Quality:'''
BU
Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2006 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|38.6|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|25.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:'''
â¬31-â¬35{{cite web | url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=30 | title=J.V. Snellman coin | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}
â¬36-â¬49{{cite web | url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID540 | title=J.V. Snellman coin (Proof) | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| [[Johan Vilhelm Snellman]] (12 May 1806 â 4 July 1881) was an influential Finnish philosopher, writer, journalist and statesman, who championed Finnish culture and developed the structures of the modern civic society. Apart from developing the national education system and the Finnish language, Snellman, in his capacity as Senator and head of the fiscal committee, also introduced a monetary reform that granted Finland a currency of its own, the Finnish markka, in 1865. For this achievement, there is a statue of J.V. Snellman in front of the [[Bank of Finland]] building in [[Helsinki]]. The obverse depicts J.V. Snellman, It also depicts the logo of the [[Europa Coins|Europe Coins Programme]]. The reverse design features represent the dawn of Finnish culture. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Finnish parliamentary election, 1907|100th Anniversary of the Finnish Parliamentary]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Pertti MÃ¤kinen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''
10,000
20,000 | align=center | '''Quality:'''
BU
Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2006 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|38.6|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|25.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:'''
â¬28-â¬35{{cite web | url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=30 | title=100th Anniversary of the Finnish Parliamentary coin | publisher=Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}
â¬36-â¬49{{cite web | url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=616 | title=100th Anniversary of the Finnish Parliamentary coin (Proof) | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This issue celebrates the [[Finnish parliamentary election, 1907|100th Anniversary of the Finnish parliamentary reform]] that brought universal and equal suffrage to Finland as the first country in Europe. The obverse shows the silhouette of a woman's and a man's hands, and below the hands ballots being inserted in a ballot-box. The Finnish word ''eduskuntauudistus'' (parliamentary reform) can be seen in this side of the coin. On the reverse, two stylized faces in the centre part, one male and the other female, separated by a thin curved line is depicted. They symbolize the equality of genders, as does the fact that the pictorial subjects on both sides are equal in respect to the centre of the coin. |} ==2007 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 90th Anniversary of [[Finland's Declaration of Independence]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center| '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center| '''Alloy:'''
Center: Cu (Copper) & Ni (Nickel)
Ring: Al (Aluminium) & Pr (Bronze) | align=center| '''Quantity:'''
130,000
20,000 | align=center| '''Quality:'''
[[Coin grading#Overview|BU]]
[[Coin grading#Overview|Proof]] |- | align=center| '''Issued:''' 2007 | align=center| '''Diameter:''' {{convert|35|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Weight:''' {{convert|19.81|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Market value:'''
â¬14.50-â¬16
â¬23.50 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| On 15 November 1917, the [[Bolshevik]]s in Russia declared a general right of self-determination, including the right of complete secession, "for the People of Russia". On the same day the [[Parliament of Finland|Finnish Parliament]] issued the [[Finland's Declaration of Independence]], a declaration by which it assumed all powers of sovereignty in Finland. On 6 December 1917, the Parliament adopted the Declaration, which is why this day is the national holiday [[Finland Independence Day]]. The independence of Finland was recognized by the [[Government of the Soviet Union|Soviet government]] on 18 December and approved on 22 December of the same year. This issue celebrates the 90th anniversary of independence in Finland. The [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] shows [[petroglyph]] aesthetics, while the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] has a nine-oar boat with rowers as a symbol of a true Finnish trait: collaboration. You can also distinguish signs of music and Finnish [[kantele]] strings in the coin's design.{{cite web| url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=1309| title=2007 Finland â¬5 "1917 Independence" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} |- | colspan="5"|   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 90th Anniversary of [[Finland's Declaration of Independence]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center| '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center| '''Alloy:''' Au 900 (Gold) | align=center| '''Quantity:''' 9,000 | align=center| '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center| '''Issued:''' 2007 | align=center| '''Diameter:''' {{convert|22|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Weight:''' {{convert|8.48|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Market value:''' â¬304-â¬377{{cite web| url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=1312| title=Finland â¬100 Gold Proof "1917 Independence" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint| accessdate=2008-08-04}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This issue also celebrates the 90th anniversary of independence in Finland. The 100 euro coin is festive in its expression and its obverse illustrates Finland and the years of independence. The purely abstract composition on the reverse is very rare in Finnish collector coins.{{cite web| url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=1312| title=2007 Finland â¬100 Gold Proof "1917 Independence" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} |- | colspan="5"|   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Adolf Erik NordenskiÃ¶ld]] and [[Northern Sea Route|Northeast Passage]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center| '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center| '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center| '''Quantity:''' 7,000
33,000 | align=center| '''Quality:'''
BU
Proof |- | align=center| '''Issued:''' 2007 | align=center| '''Diameter:''' {{convert|38.6|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Weight:''' {{convert|25.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Market value:'''
â¬30-â¬35{{cite web| url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=936| title=Finland â¬10 Silver BU "A.E. NordenskiÃ¶ld" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-08-04}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}
â¬35-â¬49{{cite web| url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=937| title=Finland â¬10 Silver BU "A.E. NordenskiÃ¶ld" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-08-04}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This issue celebrates the 175th anniversary of the birth of Finnish explorer [[Adolf Erik NordenskiÃ¶ld]], and of his discovery of the [[Northern Sea Route|Northeast Passage]]. The issue is a part of the [[Europa Coins 2007|European series]] with the [[Europa coin programme|Eurostar]] mintmark, which celebrates European Achievements in 2007. The obverse features an abstract portrait of NordenskiÃ¶ld at the helm of his ship. The reverse is dominated by a pattern resembling the labyrinth formed by adjacent ice floats. |- | colspan="5"|   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Mikael Agricola]] and Finnish language |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center| '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center| '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center| '''Quantity:'''
6,000
24,000 | align=center| '''Quality:'''
BU
Proof |- | align=center| '''Issued:''' 2007 | align=center| '''Diameter:''' {{convert|38.6|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Weight:''' {{convert|25.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Market value:'''
â¬30-â¬37{{cite web| url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=1084| title=Finland â¬10 Silver BU "Mikael Agricola"| publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-08-04}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}}
â¬35-â¬49{{cite web| url=http://www.rsmint.com/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=1083| title=Finland â¬10 Silver BU "Mikael Agricola"| publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-08-04}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This collector coin is issued to honor [[Mikael Agricola]]'s lifework as a contributor of [[protestant reformation]] in Finland and father of Finnish written language. The reverse of the coin shows a quill referencing the writer; while the obverse contains an artistic interpretation of a human figure. |} ==2008 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 90th Anniversary of the [[Flag of Finland|Finnish Flag]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Tapio Kettunen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''
9,000
26,000 | align=center | '''Quality:'''
[[Coin grading#Overview|BU]]
[[Coin grading#Overview|Proof]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|38.6|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|25.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:'''
â¬37
â¬40 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This coin is part of the "Europa series 2008". The first [[Flag of Finland]], independent since late 1917, was a red and yellow lion flag. Just six monts after the declaration of independence, on 27 May 1918, a proposal on a blue and white cross flag was adopted. The Flag Act was passed two days later. In 2008, the Finnish Blue Cross flag celebrates its 90th anniversary. This is the first ever Finnish collector coin with added colour on it. The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] shows the dignified Finnish flag with the blue cross in full color in the midst of other flags. The [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] depicts Finnish nature as a cross design that nicely completes the entity. On this side, the Finnish words ''Suomen lippu'' and Swedish words ''Finlands flagga'' (Finnish flag) can be seen. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Science and Research |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Tapio Kettunen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:'''
Disk: Cu (Copper) & Ni (Nickel)
Ring: Al (Aluminium) & Pr (Bronze) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''
25,000
20,000 | align=center | '''Quality:'''
BU
Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|35|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|19.81|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:'''
â¬13-â¬14
â¬19-â¬23 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|In 2008, the Finnish Academy of Science and Letters as well as Helsinki University of Technology celebrate their 100th anniversary. In honour of this event a bimetallic collector coin was minted. The Collector Coin Committee set by the Finnish Ministry of Finance arranged a public competition for the designing of the coin. Designer Tapio Kettunenâs proposal "''LÃ¤pimurto â vihdoinkin uutta valoa''" ("Breakthrough â new light at last") emerged as the winner. The Finnish words ''100 vuotta tiede ja tutkimus'' (100 years of science and research) can be obvserved in the reverse of the coin. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Mika Waltari]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''
5,000
15,000 | align=center | '''Quality:'''
BU
Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|38.6|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|25.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:'''
â¬39-â¬54
â¬34.50 |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This coin was issued to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the birth of the important Finnish author [[Mika Waltari]] (1908â1979). Mika Waltari captivated Finnish readers as early as the 1920s; by the end of the 1940s, a worldwide readership confirmed his popularity. His best-known and most loved book was ''[[The Egyptian]]'', published in 1945. The events in the book take place in [[Egypt]] during the reigns of the pharaohs Akhenaten and Tutankhamun. Soon after publication, the book became a [[Publishers Weekly list of bestselling novels in the United States in the 1940s|best-seller in the US]], and historians praised Mika Waltari for his detailed scientific knowledge of [[Egyptology]]. The reverse depicts a vigilant [[Pharaoh]] watchdog referencing his famous book. The obverse is decorated with Waltari's signature and a stylized pen nib that symbolizes the diversity of the writerâs production. |- | colspan="5"|   |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 200th Anniversary of [[Finnish War]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Reijo Paavilainen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center| '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center| '''Alloy:''' Au 917 (Gold) | align=center| '''Quantity:''' 9,000 | align=center| '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center| '''Issued:''' 2008 | align=center| '''Diameter:''' {{convert|22|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Weight:''' {{convert|8.48|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center| '''Market value:''' â¬425{{cite web | url=http://www.rahapajamoneta.fi/wsp/shgfin/frontend.cgi?func=catalog.show&func_id=49483&table=PRODUCT&open=229 | title=200th Anniversary of Finnish War Commemorative Coin | publisher=Rahapaj Monet Finland | accessdate=2008-11-18}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This issue commemorates the 200th anniversary of the [[Finnish War]] and the Birth of Finnish Autonomy. The Finnish War was fought between [[Sweden]] and [[Russia]] from February 1808 to September 1809, with Finnish guerrilla troops helping on the Swedish side. As a result of the Russian-won war, the eastern third of Sweden was established as the autonomous [[Grand Duchy of Finland]] within the [[Russian Empire]]. Other notable effects were the Swedish parliament's adoption of a new constitution (also called [[Swedish Act of Succession]]) and the establishment of the [[House of Bernadotte]], the new Swedish royal house, in 1818.{{cite web| url=http://rsmint.com/2008finlandandeuro100goldproofcoinfinnishwar.aspx | title=2008 Finland â¬100 Gold Proof "Finnish War" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-11-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The motif on the coin is the passage from Sweden to Russia. The same coin depicts both Finnish history, with the withdrawing crown on the reverse side as well as the future of the country, with the eagle symbol on the obverse side.{{cite web | url=http://www.mint.fi/en/press-releases/1953/ | title=Golden collector coin in honour of the anniversary: two hundred years since the Finnish war and the birth of autonomy | publisher=Mint of Finland | accessdate=2008-11-18}} |} ==2009 coinage== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Fredrik Pacius]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Pertti MÃ¤kinen | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Mint of Finland Ltd. |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''
7,000
28,000 | align=center | '''Quality:'''
[[Coin grading#Overview|BU]]
[[Coin grading#Overview|Proof]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2009 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|38.6|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|25.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' N/AThis information is not available to the public yet. |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| [[Friedrich Pacius]] was a German composer and conductor who lived most of his life in [[Finland]]. He has been called the "Father of Finnish music". Pacius was appointed music teacher at the [[University of Helsinki]] in 1834. There he founded a musical society, a student choir and an orchestra. In 1848 Pacius wrote the music to the poem ''[[Maamme|VÃ¥rt land]]'' by [[Johan Ludvig Runeberg]], which was to become Finland's [[national anthem]]. Pacius's music was also used for the [[Estonia]]n national anthem ''[[Mu isamaa, mu Ãµnn ja rÃµÃµm]]'' and the [[Livonia]]n national anthem ''[[Min izÄmÅ, min sindimÅ]]''. He also composed ''[[Kung Karls jakt]]'' (''The Hunt of King Charles'') which was the first Finnish opera. This issue celebrates the 200th anniversary of his birth. The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] and [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] of the coin complement each other, forming stylized [[musical notation]]s floating in what reflects a view of a stage. This is the fifth Finnish collector coin in the [[Europa coin programme|Eurostar]] series with the pan-European mint mark. |} ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References==
